work.p: Phrases from this manuscript are similar to words and phrases that appear in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself." See "I jump from the crossbeams, and seize the clover and timothy" (1855, p. 18); "Over the western persimmon. . . . over the longleaved corn and the delicate blue-flowered flax; / Over the white and brown buckwheat, a hummer and a buzzer there with the rest" (1855, p. 36).

This phrase also resembles a line that appeared in the poem "Come Up From the Fields Father," which was first published in Drum-Taps in 1865: "Smell you the buckwheat, where the bees were lately buzzing?" (p. 39).

Phrases from this manuscript also appeared in the poem "Give Me the Splendid Silent Sun," which was first published in Drum-Taps in 1865. See "Keep your fields of clover and timothy, and your cornfields and orchards; / Keep the blossoming buckwheat fields, where the Ninth-month bees hum;" (p. 48).

This phrase also resembles a line that appeared in the poem "The Return of the Heroes," which was first published in the 1881 edition of Leaves of Grass: "Cotton and rice of the South and Louisianian cane, / Open unseeded fallows, rich fields of clover and timothy" (1881, p. 281).

a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman probably drafted this manuscript in the early 1850s as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. The discussion of the vastness of time and space is similar to a passage from the first poem in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself." Words like "timothy" and "clover" and the phrase about "the buckwheat" from this manuscript appear in the poem as well, although they were also used in later poems. The leaf looks like it may have been extracted from a notebook.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Written on the back of this leaf are several poetic lines. A phrase from one of them appeared in the poem ultimately titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

revisionDesc.change: corrected collection information (from Lion to Berg)
edited work relations information, editorial note

p.seg: Of all that there is in the this broad and majestic universe, you can mention nothing either all in the visible world, or and much in the greater world invisible, that is not but what is owned by the Poet.—
He owns the solid ground and tills it and reaps from every field and harvests fro the cotton and grain, dried grass. the timothy and the clovers.—.—
All the woods and all the orchards—the corn, with its ear and stalks and tassels—the buckwheat with and its sweet white blossoms tops where and the bees that hum there all day—
